intro: Placus bifrons, commonly known as the two-faced liverwort, is a type of non-vascular plant belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its distinctive leaf structure, with two different types of leaves on either side of the stem, giving it its common name. This plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. Its small, lobed leaves are often arranged in a spiral pattern around the stem. Placus bifrons plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for various microorganisms.
